title: Health, Cognition, Family, and Employment among Men
descriptions:
The proposed project, "Health, Cognition, Family, and Employment among Men," aims to investigate how men's changing family and working lives impact their health and cognition. With a focus on improving men's health and cognition, the project seeks to address the gender disparities in premature mortality rates and preventable excess mortality among men. By exploring trends in family and working lives, such as the increasing role of men in caregiving and the loss of the male breadwinner model, the project aims to enhance gender equality and societal contributions.

The research will focus on men in young adulthood and midlife, examining cohort and period differences, the work-face interface, the male breadwinner model, and fathers' participation in childcare. By utilizing a methodology that disentangles selection and causality, the project will analyze data from Norwegian population registers, surveys, and genetic data, as well as health measures and employment data. With a sample size of over 12,000 men spanning from late teens to midlife, the project will provide insights into the complex interactions between family, work, health, and cognition.

The funding for this project is currently pending, but with the potential to extend our understanding of men's health and cognition in the context of evolving family and work dynamics, this research has the opportunity to make significant contributions to both academic knowledge and societal well-being.
